hedline.hl1: For Princeton's McCarter, A New 350-Seat Theater

abstract.p: New 350-seat theater is planned as contemporary complement to Princeton University's McCarter Theater; new house will be called Berlind Theater; diagram (S)

block.p: To the Gothic tower and arches of the McCarter Theater at Princeton University, a new, more intimate playhouse -- the Berlind Theater -- is to be added, with construction starting early next year.

Named in honor of the Broadway producer Roger S. Berlind, a 1952 Princeton graduate, the 29,000-square-foot building with its 350-seat theater is intended as a contemporary complement to the 71-year-old, 1,100-seat McCarter, which won a Tony Award in 1994 for outstanding regional theater and has seen two productions -- ''Having Our Say'' and ''Electra'' -- go on to Broadway since 1995.
To the Gothic tower and arches of the McCarter Theater at Princeton University, a new, more intimate playhouse -- the Berlind Theater -- is to be added, with construction starting early next year.

Named in honor of the Broadway producer Roger S. Berlind, a 1952 Princeton graduate, the 29,000-square-foot building with its 350-seat theater is intended as a contemporary complement to the 71-year-old, 1,100-seat McCarter, which won a Tony Award in 1994 for outstanding regional theater and has seen two productions -- ''Having Our Say'' and ''Electra'' -- go on to Broadway since 1995.
''The big stage house at McCarter has those Gothic arches, probably 80 feet tall, and the 130-foot tower,'' said Hugh Hardy of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, the new theater's architect.

''This building will be connected on the south side,'' Mr. Hardy said, ''and to complement the older building we are using patterned horizontal masonry and stone -- various patterns -- that tie to the vertical dimension of the McCarter's Gothic composition. It's the same kind of masonry, but a freer, more contemporary interpretation.''
The managing director of the McCarter, Jeffrey Woodward, said the thinking behind construction of the new theater is ''to give our artistic staff greater flexibility in programming.''
''The current theater,'' Mr. Woodward said, ''is not always conducive to small plays. And the new theater will be better suited for that kind of intimate work.''

Mr. Berlind -- a producer of ''Kiss Me, Kate,'' which won this year's Tony for best musical revival, and of ''Copenhagen,'' winner of this year's Tony for best play -- has contributed $3.5 million toward the $10.5 million cost of the new theater. So far, about $8.5 million has been pledged. Construction is expected to take 14 months.

Mr. Hardy said the new theater ''should be a spirited space where all the paraphernalia of stage production -- the lighting and catwalks and all the systems used to make theater -- become part of the design.''
